properties.text: Vertical structures made out of concrete, metal or wood. This shoreline type is widespread in the harbor making up over 180 miles. Bulkheads are widely perceived as having little value to wildlife but there is little data to confirm this.
These sloping shorelines made of boulders, sometimes called revetments, are the second most wildly used engineered shoreline type, covering over 110 miles of shoreline.

The most biologically productive natural habitat in the Harbor Estuary, tidal marshes shelter and feed both aquatic and terrestrial wildlife and provide a host of ecosystem services that clean our environment.

Beaches and other gently sloping areas of shifting fine-grained particles are a rarity in the Harbor Estuary and provide nesting habitat for key species like horseshoe crabs and endangered sea turtles.
These naturally occurring areas may look barren but they can be important habitat for animals that live in the intertidal areas.

In addition to a small wetland planted at the new Bush Terminal Piers Park, NYC parks decided to add additional in-water habitat by creating two sets of breakwaters, creating tidal pools. These pools, which are connected every high tide, can help juvenile fish hide from predators, as well as create more shallow nearshore habitat that is at a premium in the harbor.

Like much of the Harbor Estuary, Roberto Clemente Park on the Harlem River has a bulkhead along the length of its waterfront. When the park was being redesigned, in order to create more habitat for marine life, designers found a location to let the river waters on to the land. Every high tide pushes tide gates on the bulkhead open and a tidal pool is created, allowing for increased habitat and visitors to more access to the life in the river than ever before.

The NJ Sports and Exposition Authority created a living shoreline in the Meadowlands by using a rock sill to stabilize a planting of tidal marsh grass. In addition to protecting the marsh from erosion, the sill helps sediment collect behind it, thereby allowing the marsh to keep up with sea level rise. The sill is passable by marine organisms at every high tide.

Fresh Kills, once one of the country¡¦s largest landfills, has been capped and converted into a park, securing a large area of land in Staten Island as open space for habitat and eventually public access. This effort included a living shoreline created by planting marsh plants secured by a coir logs and mussels. These coir logs, made of coconut fibers are biodegrade but not until the newly planted marsh has time to establish
